item.title: Episode 28: Facial Recognition Technology Update and Rating Trustworthiness of AI-Generated Airbnb Profiles
item.description:
In this episode, we discuss a number of miscellaneous news updates regarding facial recognition technology (concerning San Francisco, Amazon, and pandas!). And then, we talk about how much we trust AI-generated profiles for Airbnb.

Sources

  • San Francisco’s facial recognition ban still lets corporations spy on you

  • Amazon’s facial recognition service is being used to scan mugshots, but it’s also used to track innocuous things like soccer balls

  • Amazon Investors Reject Proposals on Climate Change and Facial Recognition

  • Amazon facial recognition ban won just 2% of shareholder vote

  • Amazon shareholders vote down proposals on facial recognition and climate change

  • AI-generated profiles? Airbnb users prefer a human touch

  • CHI 2019 Paper: AI-Mediated Communication: How the Perception that Profile Text was Written by AI Affects Trustworthiness

item.title: Episode 27: Does Uber/Lyft Help Or Hurt Traffic Congestion and Machine Learning Interpretability
item.description:
In this episode, we look at a study about whether ride-sharing services contribute to increased or decreased traffic congestion in San Francisco. We then discuss some strategies to build interpretable machine learning models.

Sources

  • Science Advances article: Do transportation network companies decrease or increase congestion?

  • SF-CHAMP Modeling

  • KDNuggets.com: Will GDPR Make Machine Learning Illegal?

  • Interpretable Machine Learning free online textbook

  • Reddit.com: [P] Lime: Explaining the predictions of any machine learning classifier

  • UC Business Analytics R Programming Guide: Visualizing ML Models with LIME

  • arXiv.org: “Why Should I Trust You?”: Explaining the Predictions of Any Classifier

  • arXiv.org: A Unified Approach to Interpreting Model Predictions

item.title: Episode 26: Household Electronics That See and Google's Reservation AI
item.description:
In this episode, we talk about a new innovation that enables household electronics to see what’s around them. We then discuss Google Duplex, an AI designed to happily make reservations and appointments for you.

Sources

  • The Economist: Household electronics are undergoing a sensory makeover

  • The Verge: Amazon Says 100 Million Alexa Devices Have Been Sold — What’s Next?

  • Gizmodo: The Terrible Truth About Alexa

  • Bloomberg: Amazon Workers Are Listening to What You Tell Alexa

  • SurfaceSight

  • Google Duplex Demo

  • The Verge: One Year Later, Restaurants Are Still Confused By Google Duplex

  • The Verge: Google is bringing Duplex to the web to help book car rentals and movie tickets

  • Forbes: What You Need To Know About Chatbots

item.title: Episode 25: DataFest 2019 and Measuring Migrations from Hurricane Maria
item.description:
Susan recently served as a judge at a local DataFest competition (a weekend-long data competition for undergraduates). She shares her experiences and recommendations for future contestants. We then discuss how Facebook data might be helpful for counting the number of people how migrated from Puerto Rico to the mainland U.S. as a result of Hurricane Maria.

Sources

  • ASA Datafest Website

  • Science News: Facebook data show how many people left Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria

  • Research article: The impact of Hurricane Maria on out-migration from Puerto Rico: Evidence from Facebook data

  • Puerto Rico One Year After Hurricane Maria

item.title: Episode 24: Predictive Power of Early Polling and Did a TV Show Result in Higher Teenage Suicides?
item.description:
In this episode, we discuss FiveThirtyEight.com’s analysis of primary election polling over the past 40 years. In particular, we consider whether early polling is helpful for predicting election outcomes. And then, we talk about a study that potentially blames Netflix for a surge in teenage suicides in 2017.

Sources

  • We Analyzed 40 Years Of Primary Polls. Even Early On, They’re Fairly Predictive.

  • Research Article: Association Between the Release of Netflix’s 13 Reasons Why and Suicide Rates in the United States: An Interrupted Times Series Analysis

  • NPR: Teen Suicide Spiked After Debut Of Netflix’s ‘13 Reasons Why,’ Study Says

  • Spurious Correlations

item.title: Episode 23: Offline Song Identification and Perceptions about AI
item.description:
In this episode, we discuss how Google’s Now Playing feature can identify songs that are playing around you, using embeddings. We then talk about a study that reports on America’s perceptions about artificial intelligence – who can we trust to develop AI responsibly?

Sources

  • Google’s Pixel 2 Phones Recognize 17,300 Songs Offline

  • Google’s Next Generation Music Recognition

  • Word2Vec tutorial

  • Artificial Intelligence: American Attitudes and Trends

  • SOCIETY Report: The public is unconvinced AI will benefit humanity

  • Vox: The American public is already worried about AI catastrophe

  • U.S. Military Trusted More Than Google, Facebook to Develop AI

item.title: Episode 22: Betting on the Game of Thrones and the Misfortune of Lefthandedness
item.description:
In this episode, we discuss how bookmakers price/take bets on outcomes in the Game of Thrones. We then discuss a study that claimed that lefthanded people have shorter life expectancies than righthanded people. Spoiler alert: lefthanders have nothing to worry about!

Sources

  • Pinnacle.com: How Bookmakers Work

  • Mybookie.ag: Game of Thrones Bets

  • ‘Game of Thrones’ Betting Halted After Suspicious Rash of Wagers on Long Shot to Win Iron Throne

  • OddsShark: Bet on Who Will be Ruling Westeros

  • Nature.com: The power of prediction markets

  • Psychology Bulletin: Left-handedness: a marker for decreased survival fitness.

item.title: Episode 21: Pitch Call Accuracy and Predicting the Outcome of the Champions League
item.description:
Buckle up for a sports-filled episode! We discuss a study that analyzes the accuracy of umpire calls about strikes vs. balls and take a deep dive into FiveThirtyEight.com’s statistical methods for predicting the winner of the Champions League.

Sources

  • MLB Umpires Missed 34,294 Ball-Strike Calls in 2018. Bring on Robo-umps?

  • Official Baseball Rules 2018

  • FiveThirtyEight: Champions League Predictions

  • FiveThirtyEight: How Our Club Soccer Predictions Work

item.title: Episode 20: Thinking Like Computers and Text Mining the Mueller Report
item.description:
In this episode, we discuss a study that recruits human researchers to try to predict how computers classify images. We then highlight a number of examples of natural language processing techniques applied to the Mueller Report.

Sources

  • Researchers get humans to think like computers

  • Nature Communications: Humans can decipher adversarial images

  • Mueller Report and “Data Science” (part 1 in a series)

  • Using R To Analyze The Redacted Mueller Report

item.title: Episode 19: Seeing with AI and Detecting Exoplanets
item.description:
In this episode, we discuss Microsoft’s handy phone application for scanning and reporting on our surroundings, as a way of helping vision impaired individuals better interact with the world around them. We then talk about how AI can be useful in detecting exoplanets (or extrasolar planets).

Sources

  • Microsoft’s Seeing AI app

  • NPR: Young Astronomer Uses Artificial Intelligence To Discover 2 Exoplanets

  • “Identifying Exoplanets With Deep Learning II” paper

  • “Identifying Exoplanets with Deep Learning” paper
